description: Work out your new employee's tax code and starter declaration to set them up on your payroll software and register them with HMRC.

details.body:
You need to work out which tax code and starter declaration to use in your payroll software when you take on a new employee.

You must report this information to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) using a Full Payment Submission (FPS) on or before your new starter’s first payday.

Before you can work out your new employee’s tax code and starter declaration, you’ll need to:

  • confirm you need to pay them through PAYE
  • collect information from them - usually from their P45

options.label: You do not have their P45

nodes.title: On their P45, when did your employee leave their last job?
On their P45, does their current tax code include BR, 0T, D0 or D1?
On their P45, does their current tax code include BR, 0T, D0 or D1?

nodes.body: You’ll need to ask your new starter for this information - known as an employee starter declaration.

options.label: This is their first job since 6 April 2023 and they have not received taxable Jobseeker's Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance, Incapacity Benefit, or a State Pension or workplace pension

This is their only job, but since 6 April 2023 they’ve had another job, or have received taxable Jobseeker's Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance or Incapacity Benefit. They do not receive a State Pension or workplace pension
They have another job or receive a State Pension or workplace pension
You’re unable to get a declaration from your employee

nodes.title: According to your employee, which of these situations applies to them?

nodes.body: You’ll need to ask your new starter about this information - known as an employee starter declaration.

options.label: This is their first job since 6 April 2023 and they have not received taxable Jobseeker's Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance, Incapacity Benefit, or a State Pension or workplace pension

This is their only job, but since 6 April 2023 they’ve had another job, or have received taxable Jobseeker's Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance or Incapacity Benefit. They do not receive a State Pension or workplace pension
They’ve got another job or get a State Pension or workplace pension
You’re unable to get a declaration from your employee

nodes.title: According to your employee, which of these situations applies to them?
When did your employee start working for you?
On their P45, does their tax code end in ‘L’, ‘M’ or ‘N’?

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Check your employee’s P45

You must check that:

  • the total tax paid to date is correct
  • the pay and tax fields are blank if ‘Week 1/month 1’ box is marked with an ‘X’
  • items 6 (‘Tax code at leaving date’) and 7 (‘Last entries on the payroll record/deductions working sheet’) of Part 3 agree with Part 2 - contact HMRC if they do not

Most payroll software can make these checks for you - use the correct figures if your software found errors in the P45.

If your software cannot make these checks, you can use HMRC’s Basic PAYE Tools.
nodes.title: Use the same tax code as on your employee’s P45, and starter declaration code B

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Check your employee’s P45

You must check that:

  • the total tax paid to date is correct
  • the pay and tax fields are blank if ‘Week 1/month 1’ box is marked with an ‘X’
  • items 6 (‘Tax code at leaving date’) and 7 (‘Last entries on the payroll record/deductions working sheet’) of Part 3 agree with Part 2 - contact HMRC if they do not

Most payroll software can make these checks for you - use the correct figures if your software found errors in the P45.

If your software cannot make these checks, you can use HMRC’s Basic PAYE Tools.
nodes.title: Use the same tax code as on your employee’s P45, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Use the same tax code as on your employee’s P45, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software and send it to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) in an Full Payment Submission (FPS) on or before your employee’s first payday.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions.
nodes.title: Use the tax code 1257L on a ‘Week 1/month 1’ basis, and starter declaration code B

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Use the same tax code as on your employee’s P45, and starter declaration code B

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Use the tax code 1257L and starter declaration code A

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Use the tax code 1257L on a 'Week 1/month 1' basis, and starter declaration code B

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Use the tax code BR, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Late starter declaration

You may need to update your payroll records if your employee gives you a starter declaration after you’ve registered them with HMRC.
nodes.title: Use the tax code 0T on a 'Week 1/month 1' basis, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Late P45

You may need to update your payroll records if your employee gives you a P45 after you’ve registered them with HMRC.

If your employee has not provided a National Insurance number

Ask them for an old payslip or P60 - the number will normally be there.

If you cannot get your employee’s National Insurance number, you should leave the field blank on the Full Payment Submission (FPS) that includes a payment to them - do not use an incorrect or ‘dummy’ number.

If HMRC are able to work out the correct National Insurance number, they’ll send it to you through an FPS (and to your employee by post). However, if you do not hear from HMRC, continue to leave your employee’s National Insurance number blank on your FPS reports.

Your employee can apply for a National Insurance number if they’ve never had one.

You can also check a National Insurance number with HMRC by using your payroll software if it has this feature, or HMRC’s Basic PAYE Tools if it does not. This is called a National Insurance number verification request (NVR).

If you’ve recently registered as an employer, you cannot request an NVR until at least 2 weeks after your first FPS report to HMRC.

If your employee has a National Insurance number beginning with ‘MA’, continue to use it and ignore messages from HMRC saying it’s incorrect.
nodes.title: Use the tax code 1257L and starter declaration code A

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

nodes.title: Use the tax code BR, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Late P45 or starter declaration

You may need to update your payroll records if your employee gives you a P45 or starter declaration after you’ve registered them with HMRC.

If your employee has not provided a National Insurance number

Ask them for an old payslip or P60 - the number will normally be there.

If you cannot get your employee’s National Insurance number, you should leave the field blank on the Full Payment Submission (FPS) that includes a payment to them - do not use an incorrect or ‘dummy’ number.

You can also check a National Insurance number with HMRC by using your payroll software if it has this feature, or HMRC’s Basic PAYE Tools if it does not. This is called a National Insurance number verification request (NVR).

If you’ve recently registered as an employer, you cannot request an NVR until at least 2 weeks after your first FPS report to HMRC.

If your employee has a National Insurance number beginning with ‘MA’, continue to use it and ignore messages from HMRC saying it’s incorrect.
nodes.title: Use the tax code 0T on a 'Week 1/month 1' basis, and starter declaration code C

nodes.body:
Record this information in your payroll software.

You should also confirm whether you need to make student loan deductions before you register your new employee with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
nodes.title: Continue to use the same employee tax code if it ends ‘L’, ‘M’ or ‘N’, and starter declaration code B
